11:11 am
PM

Don't hold your breath: ECB to announce QE extension only on 8 December
Our base-case scenario is that the ECB will extend its QE programme beyond March
2017, given subdued inflation and growth. Recent Eurozone data has been somewhat
mixed, but more resilient than feared right after the UK referendum. On balance, we
believe this gives the ECB scope to delay its decision on an extension of QE until
8 December. This could disappoint some market participants and will put pressure on
Mr Draghi to calibrate his message carefully. Instead, we expect next week's focus to
be on the Eurozone's economic performance since the UK referendum and on the new
ECB staff macroeconomic projections for 2016-18. Consequently, we think big
monetary policy decisions are unlikely on 8 September, although technical tweaks to
the QE programme could well happen. We do not envisage further rate cuts.

PM

Focus on new ECB staff macroeconomic forecasts
In its macro forecasts from June, the ECB projected GDP growth of 1.6% for this year
and 1.7% for 2017 and 2018. In light of the UK referendum, we expect a downward
revision to 1.5% for this year and 1.3-1.4% for 2017. The ECB's inflation forecast –
1.3% for 2017 and 1.6% for 2018 – might also be revised downwards, although most
likely only by a small amount.

PM

Clock is ticking for technical adjustments to the QE programme
As we have argued previously, the ECB may soon – perhaps as soon as 8 September –
have to adjust the technical rules of its QE programme if it wants to continue buying
€80bn of assets until March 2017, or longer (Will the ECB run out of German bonds to
buy soon?). We think increasing the issue limit on bonds not containing a collective
action clause (CAC) and expanding the maturity range of purchases could be easily
achieved. Scrapping the deposit rate floor and amending the rules on substitute
purchases is also a possibility. However, we regard a deviation from the capital key
allocation on purchases as unlikely. In the near term, we also see a low chance that the
ECB would expand the range of assets to include bank bonds or cut the deposit rate
unless – but this seems very unlikely, too – it is part of a more fundamental monetary
policy decision.

PM

666p??

PM

Shares in US publishing company J Wiley – which is one of Pearson’s peers in the US Higher Education business – fell nearly 7% yesterday post-its Q1 results, primarily driven by negative comments on its Education business, which saw a 14% decline overall and a 31% decline in printed books. The comments from Wiley suggest a market that is seeing increasing structural pressure; interestingly, there was also no comments from management suggesting the weakness was due to enrolment factors, which has been Pearson’s explanation for problems in its US Higher Education business, which is our biggest area of concern with the shares (estimated 45% of group profits). We expect the company to deliver another effective profit warning this year and reiterate as our key Sell, with a 470p target price.

PM

Wiley management comments on the call relating to its Education business had a more negative tone than in the past and suggested the problems in the business are increasingly taking on a structural tone. Management highlighted three factors for the weakness in Education books: (1) Rentals taking more share; (2) College book retailers (who have seen M&A consolidation) tightening their inventory purchases from publishers and (3) the increasing share of digital meaning that student purchases are happening later (they also stated that students tend to rent books later in the semester).

An interesting comment they made was the “battle” happening over price – management clarified their comments to suggest this was not between publishers but students having more options (purchase, rental, digital etc.) and that was leading to competition on price. In our view, this sounds similar to what is happening with the music industry, in that once buying patterns change (for music, CDs to singles; for US Higher Education books, new books to rentals and cheaper options), that change tends to be permanent – and negative for the sellers.

11:19 am
PM

You'll remember that we closed our post-Nikkei acquisition short on Pearson after Fallon promised a 6.5 per cent yield.

PM

Last par from Whittacker

PM

Our biggest concern with Pearson is in its US Higher Education business (estimated 45% of group profits) and, primarily, that students are shifting away from expensive textbook purchases). Wiley’s comments yesterday suggest that this shift is real and also that it appears to be gaining momentum. Pearson is extremely 2H weighted (

100% of profits for FY16E) and the news yesterday strengthens our conviction both that it will both deliver another profit warning and that its problems are primarily structural in nature.

Pearson’s guidance of 50p-55p adjusted EPS for FY16 is based on a December 31st 2015 rate i.e. $1.47 = £1. Our FY16E adjusted EPS forecast is 51.8p but that is using a $1.34 rate but, if we used this $1.47 rate, it would give a 47.3p adjusted EPS figure i.e. below guidance.

11:19 am
PM

Whittaker

PM

Campling at Northern Trust also negative on Pearson

PM

It comes after ITT Education (once a $75/share stock) was delisted after announcing plans to close all 130 College campuses and ceasing operations this month. It comes after tough sanctions but the U.S. Department of Education banned new students enrolling from receiving federal financial aid. The company is being investigated by more than a dozen state attorneys general and two federal agencies (Source: Bloomberg). The accreditation council, the gatekeeper between colleges and billions of dollars in federal financial aid, said the string of state and federal investigations, lawsuits and regulatory actions against the company call into question ITT's integrity, financial viability and ability to serve students. Part of ITT's issues are likely company specific but serve as a reminder of tougher policy that the U.S. Government put in place during 2H16.

From technology transformation pressures to ongoing regulation pressures we see Pearson's position at risk. The ‘new’ Pearson requires stable HE enrollments to meet the targets and this is before factoring in other headwinds such as SATS backlash in K-12, core slowdown, reputation risk, State renewal RFPs, US politics, EM slowdown and the rising threats of new MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) and new OER (Open Educational Resource) platforms. Pearson main attraction, the 6% DY, could come under increasing pressure if operational improvements are not possible and the same has to be paid out of the balance sheet in the future.

BE

Micro Focus has agreed to pay $2.5bn to merge with HPE's software
business in a deal that gives HPE 50.1% shareholding in Micro Focus (via
the issuance of ADSs). The deal, classified as a reverse takeover, values
HPE Software at around $8.8bn, or around 11.4x adjusted EBITDA
(source: company release). The $2.5bn payment will be financed through
newly incurred indebtedness of HPE Software, bringing pro forma net debt
/ EBITDA to c.3.3x for the combined entity. Deal completion is expected
in Q3 2017. A $400m return of value will be paid to Micro Focus
shareholders pre-completion of the HPE Software deal (that is equivalent
to $1.68 per share).

PM

(Mouselet: -- the new MF stock is being distributed to HP shareholders as ADRs)

11:26 am
BE

Background on HPE Software: a global infrastructure software
provider with greater than 50k customers, including 94 of the Fortune 100, and
around 5k partners. There are five product portfolio groupings: IT
Operations Management, Application Delivery Management, Enterprise
Security, Information Management & Governance and Big Data
Analytics. HPE will also name SUSE as its preferred Linux partner and
explore additional collaboration leveraging SUSE's OpenStack expertise
for joint innovation around HPE's Helion Openstack and Stackato
Platform-as-a-Service solutions.

PM

(It's not HP-controlled)

BE

HPE Software financials: Revenues in the 12-months to April 2016
were $3.2bn and adjusted EBITDA was $658m, including $80m in costs
which do not transfer to Micro Focus, implying an acquired EBITDA of
$738m. HPE Software revenues grew 1.5% cc in last 12 months to Q2
FY16, but declined by 1.9% in FY ‘15.

11:26 am
BE

Combined metrics. Micro Focus and HPE Software would have
combined revenues of $4.5bn and EBITDA of $1.35bn. Micro Focus
believes it can lift HPE’s adjusted EBITDA margins of 21% over time;
and in particular it plans to bring the mature assets (c.80% of revenues)
to Micro Focus' equivalent margin for mature assets of c.46% by the end
of the third full year following completion.

BE

So, to state the obvious here, it's an extremely ambitious deal.

PM

BE

BE

BE

COBOL is pretty much one of the first high-level computer languages. 1959, Wikipedia tells me. Micro Focus would go and keep your antique computers running.

11:30 am
BE

Then it went on this acquisition spree, which in spite of everything seems to have worked, so management's gone for the gigantic deal.

BE

Canaccord's excited by it.

BE

At 9.05pm last night HP Enterprise announced what we believe could become known as
the software deal of the century. Micro Focus is paying $8.8bn to acquire HPE’s software
assets to create a UK listed business with pro-forma revenues of $4.5bn and EBITDA of
$1.38bn. HPE will own 50.1% of the new entity and Kevin Loosemore and Mike Phillips
have committed to three more years as Executive Chairman and CFO respectively. The
deal is expected to be accretive from day one, but we expect the real upside to come
when Micro Focus's management starts to work its 'magic' on the 21% EBITDA margin
currently generated by its target. At TAG, a similar deal in many ways, done in 2014,
management raised margins from 33% to 46%. We see no reason why similar progress
cannot be made with the HPE software assets. We estimate this has the potential to
take the combined enterprise value from $16bn to over $20bn suggesting substantial
potential upside for the shares as debt is paid down over the two years post deal closure.

11:30 am
BE

Yep, "deal of the century" ....

BE

We've still 84 years left for that to be broken, so it's quite an argument.

PM

ECB day

11:31 am
BE

We expect the deal to be immediately accretive. First, the EV/EBITDA being paid of 11.4x
compares with around 12.0x for Micro Focus at last night’s close. Second, we expect
the net debt/EBITDA ratio to move up to 3.3x then fall to 2.5x over the next two years.
We estimate that these two factors alone will bring accretion of over 10% and this is
before operational synergies. When TAG was acquired it had margins of 33% and these
were improved to 46% over the next 18 months. HPE’s software assets have an EBITDA
margin of around 21% at the point of acquisition and we see no reason why Micro Focus
can’t get these close to 40% over a two year period. The HPE assets are expected to
contribute $738m of EBITDA to the new group and a doubling of margins could easily
imply further accretion of close to 50%.

BE

Assuming Micro Focus can get EBITDA in the acquired assets up from $738m currently
to $1.1bn simply by cost reduction, the combined EBITDA would move to $1.7bn. Based
on debt of $3.5bn, down from $4.5bn on closure, and assuming an unchanged EV/
EBITDA of 12.0x, this suggests an enterprise value of over $20bn, market cap of $17bn
and share price of £27. Therefore, we move our price target to 2700p (from 2000p) and
return to a BUY recommendation (from Hold).
Our new price target does not account for any potential upside from a commercial
deal being negotiated for HP to use SUSE software in its cloud solutions. The upside to
SUSE revenues is difficult to quantify at this stage, but at the very least we expect this
agreement to significantly increase the value of SUSE for any potential purchaser.

PM

Why do people keep saying "HPE will own 50.1% of the new entity"

11:32 am
PM

PM

BE

11:34 am
BE

PM

Sure

BE

Deal value: This is a material profit improvement, but the impact on the
share price doesn’t feel quite as compelling. If we assume that Micro Focus
fully delivers on this cost improvement and we value the combined assets on
11x EBITDA, then we justify 2850p of value. If we discount that back at 10%
for 3 years to reflect the 3yr restructuring plan, then it implies 2150p of value
today. That suggests upside, but it is worth noting that delivering $700m of
savings will involve substantial cost savings, thereby forcing a gap between
profits and cash flow. Furthermore, HP is unlikely to remain a 50%
shareholder, so there is a substantial medium term overhang.

11:35 am

shareholder

With the recently raised $300 million, and a pro forma cash
position of ~$500 million, GW is in a comfortable position to explore potential
offers or contemplate launching Epidiolex for refractory epilepsies with its
own sales force. We believe that with two positive Phase III results in two
different indications, Epidiolex has been substantially de-risked and is on its
way for potential approval in 12-15 months. We estimate that the drug has a $2
billion peak sales potential in the U.S. and in Europe. With manufacturing being
scaled up, drug supply won't represent a constraint for achieving even higher
sales. Considering the pharma-like pipeline behind Epidiolex, we would not be
surprised if competition would arise for owning the entire company. We estimate
that a takeout value could be in the vicinity of our target price ($165/ADS).

BE

(@Pharma: you misspelled "brilliant".)

I'd expect any industry bidder to have a pretty good view of that pipeline, so would be a little cautious about chasing this overly from here.

As previously stated, overall Group revenue is expected to decline, driven by the full year revenue impact of the completion of professional services contracts during FY 2016. FINKit® represents a significant opportunity for Monitise to establish long-term sustainable growth, and we will continue to invest in developing that part of our business throughout the current financial year. Overall, capital expenditure requirement is expected to be lower than in FY 2016 and we will continue to evaluate all the Group's assets to make sure that they remain relevant to our strategy and add to our value.

11:54 am
BE

Quick whip around sellside, maybe? Goldman pushing Experian.

BE

Sector piece. Very pretty. They've bought some clipart.

BE

11:56 am
BE

So ...........

BE

We believe European Business Services, which has been the best-performing sector on a 10/15-year basis in Europe, will
continue to deliver revenue and earnings growth ahead of the market. The sector, which has maintained an ROE of over
20% over the last decade due to its predominantly asset-light business models, has been benefitting from structural growth
in outsourcing and accretive cash deployment (focused on bolt-on M&A). The European listed companies have often
established profitable global or regional market leadership in specific niches, with a significant scale advantage over the rest
of the fragmented market (eg testers, Brenntag, Bunzl, Teleperformance, Amadeus, Experian, Elis, Loomis, Deutsche Post
DHL). We believe the underlying structural growth and gradual market consolidation will continue; further outsourcing
could lead the addressable market to grow from US$1.2 trn in 2015 to c.US$2.0 trn by 2025, with the leaders continuing to
gain market share.

BE

Structural outsourcing growth and M&A drive revenue growth ahead of GDP
We expect the market opportunity for European Business Services companies to continue to grow as outsourcing continues, leading
to overall addressable market growth ahead of European GDP in the coming years. Over the last decade, the companies in our
coverage have achieved 5.7% revenue CAGR, 3pp ahead of the EuroStoxx average and ahead of European GDP growth. Structural
growth is driven by increased outsourcing of labour-intensive functions, generating cost savings for the outsourcers: HR functions
are optimized, peripheral assets better utilized and operational efficiencies are improved. Additionally, continued M&A in mostly
fragmented markets should allow the market leaders to extend their competitive advantage.

11:56 am
BE

EPS in the sector could exceed 10% CAGR for several more years, with low correlation to cycle
We expect the sector to show a median organic EPS CAGR of over 7% through 2018E, as well as over 6% CAGR through 2020E;
however, we believe overall EPS CAGR could exceed 10%, well ahead of the broader European market, on the back of additional
growth from M&A (the potential value of which is included in our price targets, but not in our yearly estimates), which could add
5%-6% to topline and EPS growth for several years to come. Our analysis shows that total revenue growth of companies in our
sector has a low beta and low correlation with the European (and UK) economic cycles, indicating that they are driven more by
secular, rather than cyclical, trends, as well as by external growth.

BE

Key to success: Establish leading positions in niches, both organically and through consolidation
We find that stocks in our coverage have outperformed other European sectors on a 10/15-year basis, driven by superior earnings
growth, while multiples have expanded in line with the broader market. The companies have been able to leverage asset-light
business models, driving stable, strong cash generation and providing scope for accretive, synergistic M&A: one-third of the
companies in our coverage have spent more on M&A than on capex over the last five years, while the sector has maintained
broadly stable leverage.

BE

Many Business Services companies have leading market positions and growing market shares...
Many of the Business Services companies in our coverage are emerging as industry leaders in otherwise fragmented markets, with
leading positions in the market niches where they operate, allowing them to benefit from economies of scale and density and thus
deliver superior returns. For example, the testing companies (SGS, Bureau Veritas, Intertek, Eurofins) are the world’s largest testing
companies globally; among distributors, Brenntag is the largest chemical distributor globally and Bunzl is also market leader in its
segment; Teleperformance is the largest customer care company globally – however, in each case, the leading player has less
than a 10% market share on a global basis, indicating strong potential for consolidation.
... with further consolidation and growth in adjacent markets to come
Catering (with Compass having an 18% outsourced market share, followed by Sodexo) appears to be slightly more advanced in
terms of outsourcing and consolidation; however, several companies that currently have leading market share domestically in their
niches, such as BPOs, distributors, facility management and cash handling (eg Babcock, Capita, Elis, Rubis, Loomis,
Prosegur as well as the postal/parcel companies), have only started expanding in neighbouring markets, and we believe
consolidation will take many years to complete. Travel booking systems and IT (Amadeus), as well as credit checks and
ancillary information services (Experian), are more consolidated already, with the leaders looking to use their expertise to
expand in adjacent markets. One exception within the sector appears to be staffing companies, where the top three players have
been struggling to gain market share and consolidate the market, which has also reflected poorly (relative to the sector) in their
long-term equity returns.

11:57 am
BE

Screening for quality: Most quality names at a premium, but some are not; Experian up to Buy
With this note, we roll our valuation year to 2018 (from 2017) to determine our 12-month price targets and introduce a quality metric
to capture execution and the attractiveness of business models (looking at growth, returns and volatility), which we incorporate in
our valuation approach. We note that most quality stocks (defined as high growth, high return, low volatility) trade at a premium
versus history, yet such premium is unevenly split. On the back of this, we increase the multiples that we use in our price target
methodologies for certain stocks including Sodexo, Rubis, Teleperformance, Experian and IMCD (all Buy-rated), where we think the
market is underestimating the total growth opportunity (organic + M&A), as well as upgrade Experian to Buy (12m PT 1,845p).

PM

Er, thanks Bryce

BE

PM

BE

You also mentioned yesterday decent numbers from Plus500 suggesting CMC's problems are its own. The other one is IG, of course, which seems to be doing okay.

PM

(Ah, cheer Frank)

12:01 pm
BE

Jonathan Goslin at Numis asks how we got here.

BE

It was only six weeks ago CMC stated trading volumes had increased following the
Brexit vote and improvements in underlying client metrics were “very positive”.
This is why we found this morning’s profit warning a little surprising, especially
given the recent positive announcements from other trading firms. As a result, we
have reduced our adj. EPS estimates for 2017E/2018E/2019E by -13%-13%-12%
and our target price moves to 260p from 280p. In our view, this warning highlights
the increased level of revenue volatility we expect at CMC and justifies why we
believe it should trade at a discount to IG.

BE

● All was OK at the Q1 update (21/7/16): Active clients increased 13% which, although
partially offset by a moderate decline in average revenue per client, implies revenues
increased only slightly slower than 13% during the 3m to Jun-16. CMC then went on
to say client trade volumes had increased following the Brexit vote and improvements
in underlying client metrics were “very positive”.
● Then the wheels fell off: We estimate growth in active clients slowed to c.3% YoY in
July and August (NSe: +7%) while average revenues per user declined c.10% during
the 5m to Aug-16 relative to the same period in 2015 (NSe: +2%).
● But everyone else appears to be OK: Plus500 (5/9/16) reported current trading has
been very strong, IG Group (19/7/16) indicated current revenue growth was good while
Hargreaves Lansdown (7/9/16) noted a higher level of trading activity both pre- and
post-Brexit.
● So what went wrong: Management put the decline in revenues down to the lower
volatility providing fewer trading opportunities for clients. While we note volatility was
more subdued in July/August than in 2015, we are surprised it had so much of an
impact on revenues per customer, especially given the volatility during the summer
months is generally benign.

12:01 pm
BE

Yeah, it's definitely on the watch list now.

HPE’s software assets include Application Delivery Management, Big Data, Enterprise
Security, Information Management & Governance and IT Operations Management
businesses. We estimate c70% of this portfolio consists of relatively mature assets,
with the remaining 30% in growth areas including Big Data, Information Management,
security and software testing. These assets currently generate $738m of EBITDA and
we see scope for margins to double over the two years post deal closure based on the
margin improvement Micro Focus achieved with the TAG acquisition in 2014.
